information.title: Union Executive
information.description: The Union Executive consists of the President (Head of State), Vice-President, and Council of Ministers headed by the Prime Minister. The President is elected indirectly by an electoral college.

information.title: Powers of the President
information.description: The President of India has executive, legislative, judicial, financial, and emergency powers. However, the President exercises these powers on the advice of the Council of Ministers.

information.title: Prime Minister
information.description: The Prime Minister is the head of the government and the real executive authority. They are appointed by the President and must command the support of the majority in the Lok Sabha.

information.title: Council of Ministers
information.description: The Council of Ministers, headed by the Prime Minister, aids and advises the President in exercising his functions. The Council is collectively responsible to the Lok Sabha.

information.title: State Executive
information.description: The State Executive consists of the Governor (appointed by the President), the Chief Minister, and the Council of Ministers. The structure at the state level is similar to that at the Union level.

information.title: Chief Minister
information.description: The Chief Minister is the real executive head of the state government. They are appointed by the Governor and must command the support of the majority in the State Legislative Assembly.
